Example

Show that the algebraic fraction \(\dfrac{3}{x+1}\) and \(\dfrac{3(x+4)}{x^2+5x+4}\) are equivalent.

Solution

The denominator \(x^2+5x+4\) can be factorised as \((x+4)(x+1)\) so that

\(\qquad \dfrac{3(x+4)}{x^2+5x+4} = \dfrac{3(x+4)}{(x+4)(x+1)}\)

Note that \((x + 4)\) is a factor common to both the numerator and the denominator and can be cancelled to leave \(\dfrac{3}{x+1}\). Thus \(\dfrac{3}{x+1}\) and \(\dfrac{3(x+4)}{x^2+5x+4}\) are equivalent fractions
